Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the immediate impact of the health care reform by stating that it has already put 30 million people on health care rolls, when in reality, this number will not be reached until 2016.
Falters at times: The claim falters by not accurately representing the timeline for when the 30 million people will be added to the health care rolls.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it does not provide any evidence or data to back up the statement that 30 million people have already been added to the health care rolls.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the health care reform bill has already achieved its goal of adding 30 million people to the health care rolls, when in fact, this is a future projection.
Exist alternative explanation: An alternative explanation exists, which is that the health care reform bill will gradually increase the number of insured individuals over time, rather than immediately adding 30 million people to the health care rolls.
